Developing the Model: The habitats included mangroves, coral reefs, seagrasses, salt marshes, and sea ice. The status was calculated as a function of the amount or condition of marine habitat relative to reference states and the ranked protective ability of each habitat type.
Setting the Reference Point: The reference point compares the current extent and condition to their condition in the early 1980s.
Other Considerations: This focused on the EEZ scale and assumed that all coastal areas have equal value and equal vulnerability.

Developing the Model: The goal model was the same as in Global 2012.
Setting the Reference Point: The reference was the same as Global 2012.
Other Considerations: This approach followed the Global 2012 approach.

Developing the Model: The 12 nmi boundary was used for each habitat type for mangroves, seagrasses, coral reefs, and salt marshes. Only costal portions were used for mangroves. The total reported extent divided by the coastal area of each state was used for seagrasses. For coral reefs we calculated the extent per coastal waters of each state using maps of coral reef distribution. The salt marsh extents for some states were from national statistics.
Setting the Reference Point: The reference condition was the mean of the predicted values for 1985-1987 using regional estimations for coral reefs. The ‘current’ condition or health was the mean of the predicted values for 2008-2010.
Other Considerations: Same goal model as Global 2012, while using local data.

Developing the Model: Salt marshes, seagrasses, and sand dunes were included.
Setting the Reference Point: Temporal reference points were set for each habitat. For salt marshes, the percentage of pre-industrialized habitat coverage. For sand dunes, the habitat extent between the 1950s and 1960s.
Other Considerations: Same as Global 2012, with more ambitious reference points for target habitat coverage.

Developing the Model: See Global 2012. Sand dune was the habitat of interest.
Setting the Reference Point: Reliable, comprehensive satellite photos from 1970 enabled an evaluation of the habitat extent of the sand dunes as its reference point.
Other Considerations: Other important habitats, such as rocky reefs and the rocky intertidal flats, could not be included due to lack of data on current and/or past spatial extent and condition.

Developing the Model: The status is calculated in the same manner as in the Global assessment. Mangroves in the coastal strip (1 Km offshore and inland) were considered the main source of coastal protection, and was used for calculations.
Setting the Reference Point: The reference condition was the existing mangrove coverage in the protective area for 1991.
Other Considerations: Values are measured in units of area (km2).

Developing the Model: The approach is the same as in global assessments. Four habitats are measured: mangroves, seagrasses, salt marshes, and coral reef.
Setting the Reference Point: A temporal reference point for each habitat is set to its condition in 1980’s.
Other Considerations: These four habitats provide the most coastal protection and have available data. Not all habitat exist in all provinces and time-series data of extent is poor for some. Time-series data on the condition of each habitat is not obtainable. However, rough estimate of relative change in coverage areas since the 1980’s was found in literature.
